M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, this Honorable Court may modify an existing custody order upon a showing of a substantial and material change in circumstances that warrants a modification to serve the best interests of the child.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: In the case of Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court emphasized the paramount importance of the child's best interests when considering custody modifications.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that the best interests of the children are the paramount concern in custody-related decisions, including removal from the Commonwealth, and it evaluates the relocation and custody issues by reference to that standard. The court explains that “upon cause shown” in the removal statute means that removal must be in the child’s best interests and repeatedly frames the analysis around how to determine those best interests, while also recognizing their interrelationship with the custodial parent’s well-being. Thus, the case supports the proposition that the child’s best interests are paramount in considering custody modifications.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … The ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…’”}

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).proposition: The principles established in Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002), confirm the necessity of revisiting custody arrangements when a parent's health condition significantly impacts their ability to care for the child.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the constitutionality and construction of Massachusetts’ grandparent visitation statute and the standards (presumption in favor of fit parents, harm requirement, pleading burdens) governing third‑party visitation. It does not address modification or reconsideration of parental custody arrangements, nor does it discuss changes in custody based on a parent’s health condition. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for a principle requiring custody arrangements to be revisited when a parent’s health significantly affects caregiving ability.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).relevant_excerpt: “The statute adopts the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the test for determining visitation… To obtain visitation, the grandparents must rebut the presumption… More specifically, to succeed, the grandparents must allege and prove that the failure to grant visitation will cause the child significant harm by adversely affecting the child’s health, safety, or welfare.”

Department of Children & Families v. Abi.raw_text: Department of Children & Families v. Abigail, 480 Mass. 87 (2018)
Department of Children & Families v. Abi.proposition: Furthermore, in the case of Department of Children & Families v. Abigail, 480 Mass. 87 (2018), the court reaffirmed the obligation to ensure that the child's safety and well-being prevail in custody determinations.
Department of Children & Families v. Abi.support_reasoning: The opinion in Department of Children & Families v. Abigail, 480 Mass. 87 (2018), is not the case excerpted here; the provided text is a Massachusetts criminal case about felony-murder, aggravated kidnapping, and the merger doctrine. It does not involve the Department of Children & Families, custody, or standards prioritizing a child’s safety and well-being in custody determinations. Accordingly, this opinion does not support the cited proposition about child custody principles.
Department of Children & Families v. Abi.relevant_excerpt: We conclude that because the underlying predicate felony-kidnapping-has an intent or purpose separate and distinct from the act causing physical injury or death, aggravated kidnapping is sufficiently independent of the resulting homicide and, therefore, the merger doctrine is inapplicable. Accordingly, the omission of a merger instruction was not an error, and the defendant's motion for a new trial should not have been granted on that ground.
